body: @priyankporwal @kadirozde @gjacoby126  Please have a final review. Hoping to close this by today.

Thank you for the review @kadirozde and @priyankporwal.
@gjacoby126  @twdsilva Could you please take a look?
Thanks @gjacoby126! @kadirozde Please review these changes.

This PR is mainly for:
1. Added a new JoinTable.createSubJoinTable method to replace the old JoinTable.getSubJoinTableWithoutPostFilters.
In addition to create the new JoinTable, JoinTable.createSubJoinTable also pushs down the PostFilter to the new created JoinTable .
2. Added a JoinCompiler.PushDownPostFilterParseNodeVisitor as the visitor to  push down the PostFilter.
3. When add JoinCompiler.PushDownPostFilterParseNodeVisitor, two abstract class AndRewriterBooleanParseNodeVisitor and AndBooleanParseNodeVisitor are added to eliminate the duplicate codes with other  BooleanParseNodeVisitor(SubqueryRewriter.JoinConditionExtractor, QueryOptimizer.WhereConditionRewriter etc.)
4. Refactor JoinCompiler.WhereNodeVisitor/JoinTable and JoinCompiler.OnNodeVisitor/JoinSpec to make the modification of internal states of JoinTable and JoinSpec is sealed in  JoinTable and JoinSpec class.
When doing refactor, also rename many misleading class method names and variable names.
@twdsilva , thank you for the review, I would make a modification.
@ChinmaySKulkarni  Can you please review?

@ankitjain64 - for future reference, when you squash your commits into a single one, please also edit the commit message so that it only has the one line. 

This commit message had a line for each of the former commits, and since the UI truncated it to just show the first, I didn't notice until after I pushed the merge button. I can fix it when I push to the 4.15 branches, but since this repo doesn't allow force pushes, I think it will have to remain messy in master.

Thanks for the reviews @twdsilva @gjacoby126 and @BinShi-SecularBird. I have opened https://issues.apache.org/jira/browse/PHOENIX-5432 to introduce this refactoring in `LiteralExpression`. I will commit this change as far as the scope for this JIRA goes.

I agree with the static method is not a good design for testing, and we should spend time to refactor the code. Yes, we can create a new URL parsing utility concept class, but no reason for only one method.

Should we add a config and let people decide whether they want to enable and disable this feature? Since HConnection is kind of heavy so that they want to use the same HConnection for all tenents.

@swaroopak @dbwong @ChinmaySKulkarni

> Should we add a config and let people decide whether they want to enable and disable this feature? Since HConnection is kind of heavy so that they want to use the same HConnection for all tenents.
> 
> @swaroopak @dbwong @ChinmaySKulkarni

I don't have the best visibility into use cases outside ours but typically that is the "safest" approach.  Ping @joshelser @twdsilva does this need to be parameterized?
Jira has an example of the usecase:` different tenant wants to have different HBase config (such as HBase timeout settings)`.

I don't think we should create a new HConnection for a tenant specific connection, since its pretty heavy weight, and this could end up creating a lot of HConnections. Its fine for different tenant to use the sam CQSI as long as the rest of the config in the Properties is the same. 
If a client tries to connect to a cluster with a Properties object that is different than what is currently present in the cache, we should create a new CQSI instead of using the cached one that was created with a different configuration. Maybe you can use the Properties object to compute the hashCode of ConnectionInfo so that if a client passes in different Properties config a new HConnection is created?

@yanxinyi  Keep in mind that each CQSI has its own HConnection, and each HConnection I believe has its own ZooKeeper connection, and ZK has its own limitations for how many connections it can manage. ZK connections spawned by HConnections also tend to create a lot of threads on the client side. 

In addition, the connection-throttling framework in Phoenix is per-CQSI, so creating lots of CQSIs for similar clients  connecting to the same cluster greatly reduces the effectiveness of the throttle.
do you have any suggestions here @gjacoby126
Rebased
@ChinmaySKulkarni Addressed your comments, can you please take a look now?
Please also squash all commits and make sure your final commit has just the JIRA number and Title in it. Thanks.

> I don't think we should create a new HConnection for a tenant specific connection

Yeah, this is definitely by design. Properties should not affect the uniqueness of a ConnectionInfo (determine if a new or cached CQSI is used)

If you can come up with a way to "opt-in", I'd be OK with it. I am -1 on differing `Properties` affecting connection uniqueness by default.
